CONCEPT.LABEL: Accrete
CONCEPT.DEF:
Rumelhart and Norman (1978, 1981) have proposed three learning processes to account for human reasoning based on schema modification: accretion (an existing schema from the prior knowledge is directly used to interpret a new concept, e.g. Mercedes can be considered as another example of a car, i.e. the schema of car is instantiated to understand Mercedes),
Similar to Piaget's assimilation

CONCEPT.LABEL: Tune
CONCEPT.DEF:
Rumelhart and Norman (1978, 1981) have proposed three learning processes to account for human reasoning based on schema modification:
tuning (an existing schema has to be slightly changed in order to understand a new concept, e.g. a schema for car may be modified to include a new property . engine_power . or to modify the value of an existing property . number_passengers are less than 6), and
PiagetAccommodation

CONCEPT.DEF: Another name of "Get attention" and "Gain attention"

CONCEPT.LABEL: Inform feedback
CONCEPT.DEF: This action means that the doer inform learners of something which can be feedback information. This focuses on the target object of the action. This is different from "Give feedback", which is a sub-class of Way-implied action which lets a learner a Cognitive action".

Creating situation
CONCEPT.DEF: Preparation is done by arranging communicative state

CONCEPT.LABEL: Knowledge state
CONCEPT.DEF:
This is a state related to the development of knowledge.
Sub-classes are from revised Bloom's taxonomy Anderson, L.W., and Krathwohl (Eds.). (2001). A Taxonomy for Learning, Teaching, and Assessing: A Revision of Bloom's Taxonomy of Educational Objectives. New York: Longman.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Developmental event
CONCEPT.DEF: Its granularity is the largest and is used as the root of I_L event decomposition.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Developmental state
CONCEPT.DEF: This is a state related to the development of knowledge, skill, and competency (of human)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Perception level
CONCEPT.DEF:
The ability to use sensory cues to guide motor activity. This ranges from sensory stimulation, through cue selection, to translation.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Set level
CONCEPT.DEF:
Readiness to act. It includes mental, physical, and emotional sets. These three sets are dispositions that predetermine a person's response to different situations (sometimes called mindsets).
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Guided Response level
CONCEPT.DEF:
The early stages in learning a complex skill that includes imitation and trial and error. Adequacy of performance is achieved by practicing.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Mechanism level
CONCEPT.DEF:
This is the intermediate stage in learning a complex skill. Learned responses have become habitual and the movements can be performed with some confidence and proficiency.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Complex Overt Response level
CONCEPT.DEF:
The skillful performance of motor acts that involve complex movement patterns. Proficiency is indicated by a quick, accurate, and highly coordinated performance, requiring a minimum of energy. This category includes performing without hesitation, and automatic performance. For example, players are often utter sounds of satisfaction or expletives as soon as they hit a tennis ball or throw a football, because they can tell by the feel of the act what the result will produce.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Adaptation level
CONCEPT.DEF:
Skills are well developed and the individual can modify movement patterns to fit special requirements.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Origination level
CONCEPT.DEF:
Creating new movement patterns to fit a particular situation or specific problem. Learning outcomes emphasize creativity based upon highly developed skills.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Multi-actor action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which have multiple doers.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Single-actor action
CONCEPT.DEF:
Actions whose has only one actor.
The doer of this action is only one.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Physical action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions on physical things. This action changes the external state of the doer or the object.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitive action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions done in actor's head. This action changes internal state of the doer or the object.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Object action
CONCEPT.DEF:
Actions on objects(anything other than actions).
Action about physical thing other than action

CONCEPT.LABEL: Primitive action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which include their way of implementation. They are not decomposed further in this ontology, but it doesn't mean they can't be decomposed.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Physical state action
CONCEPT.DEF:
Actions which change physical state of object.
They need "way knowledge" to decompose them into subactions but it is implicit.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Physical subject state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change doer's state. This action focuses on the change of states of the doer.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Physical object state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change state of target object.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Meta action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions on action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Ask
CONCEPT.DEF: The object asked is information content rather than an action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Process-centered Physical object state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions whose focal point exists in the intermediate states or process as a whole rather than the resulting state.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Result-centered Physical object state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions whose focal point exists in the resulting state rather than the intermediate states or process as a whole.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Transmit
CONCEPT.DEF: This is not directive to the recipient.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Mental action
CONCEPT.DEF:
Actions related to mental state such as attitude, feeling and attention.
This is an action related to Attitude state of the doer

CONCEPT.LABEL: Recognize
CONCEPT.DEF: To build a mental model of outside things in WM. Although it locates at the boundary between physical and cognitive actions, it is classified as a physical action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Organize
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which organize knowledge in the WM.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Recall
CONCEPT.DEF: Action which takes something in LTM and bring it to WM.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Communicative state
CONCEPT.DEF: External state of Agent related to communication with other agents or objects.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Passive com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Passive communicative state

CONCEPT.LABEL: Active com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Active communicative state

CONCEPT.LABEL: Inform
CONCEPT.DEF: Give information(same as Informative action). This is created to introduce the label "inform".

CONCEPT.LABEL: Result-centered Agent-object state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions whose focal point exists in the resulting state of the agent as the target object.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Result-centered Non-agent-object action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions whose focal point exists in the resulting state of the object(non-agent) as the target object.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Progressive action
CONCEPT.DEF: Action related to the progress of learning.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional event
CONCEPT.DEF:
This is an independent event.
This event doesn't have how it affects a learning event. The effect is described in an I_L event. Sub-classes of this class is not defined because it is a concept to describe which action is done by which agent.

SUB_L.label: Instructional event
SUB_L.def: This is an independent event.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Way-independent Let the learner Cognitive action
Have been directed
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that information is informed with some intention. This also means that some actions are required after an agent is in this state.

CONCEPT.LABEL: object state
CONCEPT.DEF: State held by an agent rather than an object.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Passive Physical subject state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change doer's state in a passive way.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Active Physical subject state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change doer's state in an active manner.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Continuous active com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Communicative states sustained for a while.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Resultant active com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Communicative states focused on the resulting state.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been received
CONCEPT.DEF: State where information has been received.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been requested
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that an agent who have this are required to do some physical action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been transmitted
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that information is just informed with no other intention. This also means that no following actions are required.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Informative action
CONCEPT.DEF: Action to give Information

CONCEPT.LABEL: Non-Informative action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change the external state of recipient.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been let
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that an agent who have this are required to do some cognitive action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Way-implied Let the learner Cognitive action
Let the learner Cognitive action
CONCEPT.DEF: This action leads recipient to do cognitive action. This change is described as "Led" in the recipient's terminal state..

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitive process action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions related to cognitive process/state.

CONCEPT.DEF: ex-name: comfirm -> Confirm the outcome

CONCEPT.LABEL: action
CONCEPT.DEF: An action is a process which has an agent as a doer.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Developmental action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions related to development of knowledge, skill and competency.

CONCEPT.LABEL: I_L scenario
CONCEPT.DEF: I_L scenario is a decomposition tree of I_L event and composed of leaves and intermediate tree structure which corresponds to the scenario model. The former collectively form scenario sequence and the latter forms design intention.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Scenario text

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional scenario text
CONCEPT.DEF: This is a representation of a scenario for learning and instruction in a representation form.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Task
CONCEPT.DEF:
Something to perform.
Partially specified Assignassignment

CONCEPT.LABEL: Phenomena
CONCEPT.DEF: No doer.

CONCEPT.DEF: Action which needs specification.

SUB_L.def: Action which needs specification.

CONCEPT.DEF: The sum of subEvent and subTree is more than one. I_L event decomposition tree

CONCEPT.LABEL: Anything
CONCEPT.DEF: Terms used in this ontology are "Paradigm-independent" which is the KEY property of it.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Common world
CONCEPT.DEF: CW consists of all things that exist and that are relevant in this context and needed by the other worlds.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning world
CONCEPT.DEF: LW contains the things that are specific to learning. It refers to the things in the CW.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional world
CONCEPT.DEF: IW contains the things that are specific to instruction. It refers to the things in the CW.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Attribute of learning
CONCEPT.DEF: Attribute of learning are Attributes of the things that belong to the LW, such as learner, learning material or learning domain.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional process
CONCEPT.DEF: Instructional process contains

CONCEPT.LABEL: process
CONCEPT.DEF: Process can exist at any time during its life time.

CONCEPT.LABEL: What to learn
CONCEPT.DEF: By "What to learn", we mean all things to be learned by learners. Therefore, it covers domain knowledge, skills and competency, that is, everything. We think there is no better name other than it.

CONCEPT.LABEL: L.Entity
CONCEPT.DEF: A Learning entity is a component of learning, such as learning process and learning object

CONCEPT.LABEL: World of cognition
CONCEPT.DEF: World of Cognition contains the things that are specific to the World of Cognition. It refers to the things in the CW and the world of learning.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning
CONCEPT.DEF: This is designed with the intention to have a common framework for learning models, ie interpretations of the human learning phenomenon. It is characterized by learners, what learning outcome is expected, what learning events are expected, what knowledge models are assumed, and what learning goals are expected.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Knowledge model
CONCEPT.DEF: Learning is based on this. Knowledge model is the key factor of characterizing LT. Knowledge model is characterized as (1)its style: Performance-based or Knowledge-based, (2)its framework: Black-box mode, Information processing model or Knowledge building model, and (3)its computational mechanism: stimulus-response mechanism, cognitive mechanism, or constructivism mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning mechanism
CONCEPT.DEF: Basic computational mechanism for knowledge models.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning material
CONCEPT.DEF: It is composed of one or more Learning objects each of which has an attribute called Learning item and organized in a hierarchical or network structure.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Association mechanism
CONCEPT.DEF: It is the core of weighted graph and "strength" represents that of the association.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Information processing mechanism
CONCEPT.DEF: IT is composed of CPU, LTM and WM. Its performance demonstrates intellectual skills.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Behaviorism learning
CONCEPT.DEF: It is characterized by the increase of the performance of the learning outcome.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Stimulus-response model
CONCEPT.DEF: Its style is Performance-based, its framework is Black-box model and its mechanism is Association mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Construction mechanism
CONCEPT.DEF: There is no "internal" model like behaviorism and cognitivism in constructivism because they don't try to explain what happening in the mind. Therefore, what we can have is "external" model like this which is composed of interactive event in an authentic context. Knowledge is built through the interaction.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning event
CONCEPT.DEF: This is an independent event.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Preparing learning condition
CONCEPT.DEF:
An event of preparing learning conditions.
If learning conditions are satisfied, then the learning theory guarantees the learning action is successful.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Effect of learning
CONCEPT.DEF:
A learning action is performed.
A learning theory can tell us what effect is expected after this learning action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Interactive event
CONCEPT.DEF: Constructivism theories require involvement of learners in Interactive events to enable them to build knowledge.

CONCEPT.LABEL: I_L event
CONCEPT.DEF: A paired event consisting of instructional and learning events. From instructional perspective, there is always learning event associated with it.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitivism learning
CONCEPT.DEF: It is characterized as the change of the knowledge state and the state after learning is expected better than that of before. Its Knowledge model is based on Cognitive model.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitive model
CONCEPT.DEF: Its Style is Knowledge-based, its framework is Information processing model, and its mechanism is Cognitive mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Constructivism learning
CONCEPT.DEF: It is characterized by learning outcome and learning model. The idea of its learning is "Meaning creation" after learning on the basis of Constructivism model as the Knowledge model.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Constructivism model
CONCEPT.DEF: Its Style is also Knowledge-based which is the same as Cognitive model, its framework is Knowledge building model, and its mechanism is Constructivism mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Socio-constructivism learning
CONCEPT.DEF:
Its essential property is still on its knowledge model, that is, knowledge is built(meaning is created) by learners.
Another critical property is sociality(socialness), that is, the idea of knowledge exists in a society and learners moves from peripheral to central as learning proceeds.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Socio-constructivism model
CONCEPT.DEF: As a computational model, the major difference between socio- and non-socio is its interactive event learners are involved in. In Socio- case, it is social events in which learners are requested to participate.

CONCEPT.LABEL: ID-ISD world
CONCEPT.DEF: ID-ISD contains the things that are specific to ID and ISD. It refers to the things in the CW.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Reciprocal I_L event
CONCEPT.DEF: Trivial pair of the instructional and learning events. By trivial, I mean no theory is necessary to explain the (causal) relation between the two.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Tell_Listen event
CONCEPT.DEF: I f you tell him/her, he/she listens.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Simple event
CONCEPT.DEF: In this event, no influence on learner is made by the instructional event.

SLOT.label: slot
SLOT.DEF: other goals than to improve learning, such as: selection, classification or diagnosis (about excellence, disabilities, etc)

SUB_L.label: slot
SUB_L.def: other goals than to improve learning, such as: selction, classification or diagnosis (about excellence, disabilities, etc)

CONCEPT.LABEL: entity
CONCEPT.DEF: It corresponds to so-called "Things" and includes Physical, Abstract and Semi-abstract things.

CONCEPT.LABEL: substrate
CONCEPT.DEF: It is the infrastructure of the real world and includes Space and Time.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional goal
CONCEPT.DEF: Instruction can have two kinds of goals: assess or foster

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional strategy
CONCEPT.DEF: precisely speaking, it is representation.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning environment
CONCEPT.DEF: A Learning environment is an environment in which learning happens (natural) or is expected to happen or which is made to support learning

CONCEPT.LABEL: Learning process

CONCEPT.LABEL: Theory
CONCEPT.DEF:
a theory is 'a a conceptual system that: - describes a phenomenon - explains it (hypothesis or proof) - provides laws or principles -provides taxonomies - provide methodologies - can allow predictions
-is refutable. Refutable means that the conceptual system to explain the phenomena, together with either the hypothesis or the proof, is clearly exposed and documented with a rationale, a critique of previous or other current theories, has a clear argumentation, clear methodology, etc... so that it can be refuted. It a characteristic of science, and theory belongs to the world of science.

SLOT.label: slot22
SLOT.DEF: The distinctive characteristic of operant conditioning relative to previous forms of behaviorism (e.g., Thorndike, Hull) is that the organism can emit responses instead of only eliciting response due to an external stimulus

SLOT.label: slot
SLOT.DEF: Reinforcement is the key element in Skinner's S-R theory. A reinforcer is anything that strengthens the desired response. It could be verbal praise, a good grade or a feeling of increased accomplishment or satisfaction

SLOT.label: slot22
SLOT.DEF: learning is a function of change in overt behavior. Changes in behavior are the result of an individual's response to events (stimuli) that occur in the environment. A response produces a consequence such as defining a word, hitting a ball, or solving a math problem. When a particular Stimulus-Response (S-R) pattern is reinforced (rewarded), the individual is conditioned to respond

SLOT.label: slot42
SLOT.DEF: Cognitive structures change through the processes of adaptation: assimilation and accommodation. Assimilation involves the interpretation of events in terms of existing cognitive structure whereas accommodation refers to changing the cognitive structure to make sense of the environment. Cognitive development consists of a constant effort to adapt to the environment in terms of assimilation and accommodation

SLOT.DEF: ACT* supports three fundamental types of learning: generalization, in which productions become broader in their range of application, discrimination, in which productions become narrow in their range of application, and strengthening, in which some productions are applied more often. New productions are formed by the conjunction or disjunction of existing productions

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instruction
CONCEPT.DEF:
Instruction is an action taken by an instructor (role) to foster or assess learning, through an instructional event and using instructional tools, and supported (+ or less) by principles (from theories).
Why the class Instruction has no sub-classes is because: 1) it is defined as a generic entity like Learning in the LW 2) Instructional strategies are defined under Instructional process 3) Concrete versions of Instructional strategies are defined as Ways of instructing are called Educational strategies, to be found in the relational concept pane.

SUB_L.label: Learning
SUB_L.def: This is desinged intended to have a common framework for learning models. It is characterized by learners, what learning outcome is expected, what learning events are expected, what knowledge models are assumed, and what learning goals are expected. The last might be unnecessary in this level of abstraction.

CONCEPT.LABEL: ISD
CONCEPT.DEF: Instructional System Development is the development of Systems to foster learning such as Interactive Learning Systems.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Delivery strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Delivery strategies are those decisions affecting the way the information will be carried to the student. Delivery strategies affect the selection of the instructional media that will be used to present the learning activities.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Management strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Management strategies are those decisions affecting the way the individual student will be helped to interact with learning activities. Management strategies involve motivational techniques, individualization schemes, scheduling, resource allocation, and other implementation activities.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Macro strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Macro strategies are concerned with the selection, sequence, and organization(structure) of the subject-matter topics that are to be presented.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Micro strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Micro strategies are concerned with the individual displays --- including their characteristics, interrelationships, and sequence --- that are to be presented to the student. Micro strategies also be characterized as presentation strategies because they are concerned with the details of each individual presentation to the student.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.
